The crystallographic r(Zn-Cl) bond lengths are 2.282, 2.262, 2.274 and 2.238Å, which assumes a T d  symmetry of the metal chromophore, and we further attempted to correlate the crystallographic geometries and BOs obtained by the two completely different methods of NBO and AIM (). Preliminary, it is important to point out that, as it was shown above, the BO values according the AIM computations lack rigorous application and thus they cannot be direct correlated as quantities with the NBO bond orders. However, the BO values shown in  assume a lack of bonding interactions according to the description already written in the theory and computations section, which qualitatively correlates with the conclusions about the BO values from NBO analysis, with values obtained in the ranges 0.3114-0.3245 and 0.2882-0.3025 (NLMO), indicating the lack of complete single bond formation. The latter data seek to provide additional evidence to support the statements above by analysing the natural ionicity parameters. The predicted hybridization of the d-orbitals of the Zn2+ ion by the AIM method () agrees well with the obtained natural electronic configuration for Zn: s0.583d9.994p0.725p0.02. The same conclusions are obtained employing fuzzy and Laplacian bond orders (Figs.   and ). In all cases positive LBOs are found, which assumes a lack of covalent bonding. The correlative analysis performed between the geometry bond lengths, FBOs and LBOs shows a linear relationship with confidence levels of 99.96-96.98%. The correspondence of the chemometric data between the FBO and LBO values indicates unexpectedly high confidence levels (98.67-89.14%). These good-to-excellent linear extrapolation data are mainly found correlating BOs and bond lengths of the metal chromophore in Zn2+ complexes with the strong electronegative Cl- ligand or for cases when strong electron localization occurs. On the contrary, complexes of Ag+ and Cu2+ ions, due to 2D delocalization, exhibit a decreasing reliability of the linear extrapolation. Confidence levels of 82 (8) and 61% (9) are obtained. However, the results concerning the latter cases of strongly delocalized systems do not clearly indicate a non-linear correlation. On this basis, it might be concluded that further systematic correlative analyses are needed between theoretical and experimental EDs of AgI and CuII complexes to determine any quantitative correlations, including distinguishing between the coordination behaviour between both ions, as there is no obvious explanation, even interpreting the results on the basis of the concept of the d9d' configuration of the AgI ions presented above, for the similar behaviour of AgI and CuII ions. In the latter case, there is the well known strong Jahn-Teller effect. The data of the statistical analyses on the nature of the Zn-Cl bond in T d  ZnClxNy chromophores as a function of the content of N centres in the inner coordination sphere, showing a linear correlation, allow the conclusion that even purely ionic interactions between the charged species, like Zn2+ and Cl- ions, could be affected by other non-covalent interactions within the framework of the inner coordination sphere. If we use the above discussed concept about the LBO, where negative values are associated with the covalence of the corresponding bond, then with increasing N centres (x =0-2) there is an increase in the LBOs, which indicates a further increase in the ionic character of the Zn-Cl bonds. From the perspective of the latter BOs analyses, it can be said that the FBO and LBO results fit well to the natural electronic configurations, which in the case of the Ag+ ions in 1 are Ag1 s0.204d5.005p0.116d0.017p0.01, Ag19 s0.994d5.005p2.806s0.015d0.306p0.187s0.176d0.02 and Ag24 s1.004d5.005p2.896s0.335d0.826p0.276d0.02, thus indicating a significant orbital delocalization of the ED, by contrast to the Zn2+ complexes where a configuration for Zn1 of s0.443d9.984p0.594d0.015p0.01 is obtained. Additional confirmation can be obtained by examining the NBO E(2) values for complex 1, where by contrast to the ZnII complex discussed above (E(2) ~2.5kcalmol-1), the E(2) values of the Ag1O6 unit (complexes) are in the range 1.77-11.35kcalmol-1. The values provide significant evidence about the CT effects. By contrast, the E(2) values for the complex unit (Ag19-Ag24)O2 are in the range 0.04-0.13kcalmol-1. An exception is seen for the E(2) D→A value of 3.69kcalmol-1, corresponding to the M→L CT effect between the Ag19-O22(SO2) fragment.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st065">Conclusion</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0075" view="all">Presumably, talking about coordination chemistry of transition metal ions with the completed electronic configuration d<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup> we ought to be able to expect a dominating electrostatic character, in particularly, highlighting the behaviour of the metal ions with higher oxidation states. However, research efforts in the recent two decades have resulted in an immense body of experimental evidence showing a great chemical reactivity and diversity towards the coordination/bonding fashions of Ag<ce:sup loc="post">I</ce:sup> and Zn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> complex species, including a remarkable competitive catalytic activity compared with the well-established organometallic catalysing agents based on the complexes of Ru<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup> and Pd<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> ions. There is also experimental and theoretical support to the view that a tendency for covalent type bonding occurs even when the ligand exhibits electronegativity. All these findings need to be examined from the perspective of a correlative analysis between molecular structure-electronic structure-bonding character-chemical reactivity. In order to investigate this, we elected to study experimental high resolution crystallographic and theoretical electron densities using advanced quantum chemical approaches, including the quantum chemical topology of nine complexes of Ag<ce:sup loc="post">I</ce:sup> and Zn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> ions, which depend on the geometry of the metal-chromophore and electronic properties of the dentate ligands in the inner coordination sphere. Our best conclusions are as follows. (<ce:italic>a</ce:italic>) An explicit statistical quantitative correlation between the experimental crystallographic potential energies at the M–L bond critical points and quantum chemically predicted bond dissociation energies show that with an increase in the number of N centres in the inner coordination sphere of the {[ZnCl<ce:inf loc="post">x</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">y</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">z</ce:sup>} chromophore there is an increase in the Zn–Cl bond strengths. The linear approximations have confidence levels of 93.32 and 99.95%. The presence of only one N atom in the inner coordination sphere causes a decrease in the ionic character of the Zn–Cl bonds of about 5%. (<ce:italic>b</ce:italic>) Contrary to the Zn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> complexes, in the Ag<ce:sup loc="post">I</ce:sup> containing complexes an increasing in the tendency for covalent character of the M–L interactions occurs. Natural ionicity values are up to i<ce:inf loc="post">AB</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−0.00494. <ce:italic>(c</ce:italic>) An excellent agreement between the experimental and theoretical topological potential energies at the bcps is found. The lowest value of V<ce:inf loc="post">c</ce:inf> is ∼−0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>a.u. Bohr<ce:sup loc="post">−3</ce:sup>. The chemometrics yield confidence levels in the range 91.11–98.89%. As can be deduced, the lack of a strong contribution of electrostatic forces in the Ag–N interactions yields decreased bond strengths. In this context we would like to say that classical concepts about M–L bonding in these metal ions has been found to be valid only in cases of high symmetry inorganic chromophores, for instance, {[ZnCl<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup>} and {[Zn(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>}, with strong electronegative dentate centres. With a decrease in symmetry of the metal chromophore and an increase in the number of N–dentate centres in the inner coordination sphere a deviation from the above-mentioned concept is established. We may state, therefore, that the generally strong electrostatic interactions in Zn–Cl bonds are affected significantly due to MLCT or LMCT effects in the presence of N centres in the inner coordination sphere, which is associated with a different electronic configuration of the metal ion. Our results call for considerable further research efforts, systematically studying metal-organics with the d<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup> metal ion configuration, depending on the local symmetry of the metal chromophore, electronic properties of dentate centres in inner coordination spheres and environmental factors, in order to corroborate such as findings like those stated above.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

Presumably, talking about coordination chemistry of transition metal ions with the completed electronic configuration d10 we ought to be able to expect a dominating electrostatic character, in particularly, highlighting the behaviour of the metal ions with higher oxidation states. However, research efforts in the recent two decades have resulted in an immense body of experimental evidence showing a great chemical reactivity and diversity towards the coordination/bonding fashions of AgI and ZnII complex species, including a remarkable competitive catalytic activity compared with the well-established organometallic catalysing agents based on the complexes of RuIII and PdII ions. There is also experimental and theoretical support to the view that a tendency for covalent type bonding occurs even when the ligand exhibits electronegativity. All these findings need to be examined from the perspective of a correlative analysis between molecular structure-electronic structure-bonding character-chemical reactivity. In order to investigate this, we elected to study experimental high resolution crystallographic and theoretical electron densities using advanced quantum chemical approaches, including the quantum chemical topology of nine complexes of AgI and ZnII ions, which depend on the geometry of the metal-chromophore and electronic properties of the dentate ligands in the inner coordination sphere. Our best conclusions are as follows. (a) An explicit statistical quantitative correlation between the experimental crystallographic potential energies at the M-L bond critical points and quantum chemically predicted bond dissociation energies show that with an increase in the number of N centres in the inner coordination sphere of the {[ZnClxNy]z} chromophore there is an increase in the Zn-Cl bond strengths. The linear approximations have confidence levels of 93.32 and 99.95%. The presence of only one N atom in the inner coordination sphere causes a decrease in the ionic character of the Zn-Cl bonds of about 5%. (b) Contrary to the ZnII complexes, in the AgI containing complexes an increasing in the tendency for covalent character of the M-L interactions occurs. Natural ionicity values are up to iAB =-0.00494. (c) An excellent agreement between the experimental and theoretical topological potential energies at the bcps is found. The lowest value of Vc is ~-0.1a.u. Bohr-3. The chemometrics yield confidence levels in the range 91.11-98.89%. As can be deduced, the lack of a strong contribution of electrostatic forces in the Ag-N interactions yields decreased bond strengths. In this context we would like to say that classical concepts about M-L bonding in these metal ions has been found to be valid only in cases of high symmetry inorganic chromophores, for instance, {[ZnCl4]2-} and {[Zn(H2O)6]2+}, with strong electronegative dentate centres. With a decrease in symmetry of the metal chromophore and an increase in the number of N-dentate centres in the inner coordination sphere a deviation from the above-mentioned concept is established. We may state, therefore, that the generally strong electrostatic interactions in Zn-Cl bonds are affected significantly due to MLCT or LMCT effects in the presence of N centres in the inner coordination sphere, which is associated with a different electronic configuration of the metal ion. Our results call for considerable further research efforts, systematically studying metal-organics with the d10 metal ion configuration, depending on the local symmetry of the metal chromophore, electronic properties of dentate centres in inner coordination spheres and environmental factors, in order to corroborate such as findings like those stated above.

cln_elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st035">Materials and synthesis</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0020" view="all">5-Sulfosalicylic acid dihydrate was obtained by recrystallization of 5-sulfosalicylic acid monohydrate (Sigma–Aldrich) in water under stirring for 30<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min at 150<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C . It was used for synthesis of the Ag<ce:sup loc="post">I</ce:sup> complex of 2-hydroxy-5-sulfo-benzoic acid (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) using an equimolar mixture of acid and AgNO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (a Sigma–Aldrich product) preliminary dissolved in 5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL solvent mixture CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH:H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1:1. The mixture was heated at 40<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h. To the hot solution were added drops of 0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>M NaOH dissolved in same solvent mixture. The colorless crystals, obtained after a week, were filtered off, washed with CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH and dried on P<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf> at 298<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K. Yield: 65%. The chromatographic analysis, electro-spray ionization mass spectrometric measurements and data interpretation of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> have been presented . The crystallographic structural solution, data interpretation and analysis along with computational quantum chemical treatment are reported for first time in this paper. The crystallographic structural refinement represents a redetermination of that reported in , but here the refinement is carried out at low temperature, thus achieving a higher quality crystallographic solution and data-block. The computational quantum chemical results, including experimental and theoretical topological data, and energetics are reported here for the first time as well.</ce:para>
cln_elements.clean_text:
Materials and synthesis

5-Sulfosalicylic acid dihydrate was obtained by recrystallization of 5-sulfosalicylic acid monohydrate (Sigma-Aldrich) in water under stirring for 30min at 150°C . It was used for synthesis of the AgI complex of 2-hydroxy-5-sulfo-benzoic acid (1) using an equimolar mixture of acid and AgNO3 (a Sigma-Aldrich product) preliminary dissolved in 5mL solvent mixture CH3OH:H2O=1:1. The mixture was heated at 40°C for 2h. To the hot solution were added drops of 0.1M NaOH dissolved in same solvent mixture. The colorless crystals, obtained after a week, were filtered off, washed with CH3OH and dried on P2O5 at 298K. Yield: 65%. The chromatographic analysis, electro-spray ionization mass spectrometric measurements and data interpretation of 1 have been presented . The crystallographic structural solution, data interpretation and analysis along with computational quantum chemical treatment are reported for first time in this paper. The crystallographic structural refinement represents a redetermination of that reported in , but here the refinement is carried out at low temperature, thus achieving a higher quality crystallographic solution and data-block. The computational quantum chemical results, including experimental and theoretical topological data, and energetics are reported here for the first time as well.

</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0035" view="all">The metal–organic compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> has been described previously as a coordination polymer ([Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(HL)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O), ) crystallizing in a centrosymmetric space group (), where two Ag<ce:sup loc="post">I</ce:sup> centres are bridged <ce:italic>via</ce:italic> –SO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> functional groups from the ligand . The redetermination of the crystal structure reported in this paper, however, reveals that the structure consists of a coordination dimer {[Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(HL)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> with <ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2 (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0005"></ce:float-anchor>). In addition, strong-to-moderate bonds, <ce:italic>r</ce:italic>(Ag–O)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.506, 2.515<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, have been reported in . An Ag1<ce:sup loc="post">I</ce:sup>–Ag1<ce:sup loc="post">I</ce:sup> distance, <ce:italic>r</ce:italic>(Ag⋯Ag)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3.877<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, has been obtained as well . However a second contact interaction, Ag2<ce:sup loc="post">I</ce:sup>⋯Ag2<ce:sup loc="post">I</ce:sup>, is also determined here (<ce:italic>r</ce:italic>(Ag⋯Ag)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3.864<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). The Ag<ce:sup loc="post">I</ce:sup> ion is coordinated <ce:italic>via</ce:italic> a deprotonated –COO<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> group from the ligand, which participates monodentately in the interaction with the metal ion. Each Ag<ce:sup loc="post">I</ce:sup> ion is also bonded to two solvent water molecules as well, thus forming a distorted AgO<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> polyhedron for the metal chromophore . Cumulatively, however, the crystallographic structural solution in this paper indicates two-nuclear Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf> and Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf> non-equivalent chromophores with bond lengths: to Ag1: <ce:italic>r</ce:italic>(Ag1–O): 2.634(3), 2.403(2), 2.369(3), 2.647(2), 2.515(2), 2.695(3); to Ag2: <ce:italic>r</ce:italic>(Ag2–O): 2.473(2), 2.415(2), 2.366(3), 2.506(3), 2.509(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å ().</ce:para><ce:para id="p0045" view="all">The results of critical point analysis () and charge density models can serve as evaluation criteria for realistic inter-atomic interactions, as far as two atoms are described as chemically bonded when there are various (3,−1) bond critical points in ρ(r) between them . The Laplacian_rho(r) values<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp><<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0 () correspond to charge concentration, while the Laplacian_rho(r) values<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>><ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0 reflects charge depletion . The Laplacian_rho(r) is expressed as a sum of λ<ce:inf loc="post">i</ce:inf> parameters. As the quantum chemical topology is determined by the main contributions of core electrons, it is not possible to assign participation of pairs or bonding electrons to the M–L bond formation . The ellipticity (<ce:italic>ε</ce:italic>) parameter also provides information about the BO (s.i.). In the case of an ideal σ-bond, this leads to λ<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>–λ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and <ce:italic>bcp</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0 with λ<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> and λ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> perpendicular to the bond axes, but in the mentioned ideal case there is cylindrical symmetry along the bond axis. With increasing BO an increase in ellipticity is obtained. Complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> reveals <ce:italic>ε</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.001–0.028. The <ce:italic>ε</ce:italic> values for complexes <ce:bold>1–8</ce:bold> are 0.0–0.008, which assumes ionic character and interactions along the inter-atomic interacting axes, as well as localization of the charge, excluding the values <ce:italic>ε</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.016, 0.018 (Ag–O) in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and 0.108 (Zn–N) in <ce:bold>7</ce:bold>. If we compare the latter quantities with the <ce:italic>ε</ce:italic> values of a delocalized C<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>O double bond from the –COO<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> functional group in the organic ligand of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (<ce:italic>ε</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.028), then we could conclude that in these M–L bonds in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>7</ce:bold> there is charge de-localization, which could be associated with an intra-molecular CT effect within the AgO<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and ZnCl<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>N (<ce:bold>7</ce:bold>) chromophores. However, <ce:italic>ε</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.03–0.06 in <ce:bold>9</ce:bold>, considering data on the Cu–O and Cu–N bonds (). The effect of delocalization is comparable to the electronic effects in delocalized C<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>O groups in organic ligands, even obtaining a two times greater effect. The latter result can be addressed to the electronic configuration of the Cu<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> ions (d<ce:sup loc="post">9</ce:sup>) and the typically observed Jahn–Teller effect removing of the degeneracy of the energies of the orbitals from the <ce:italic>d</ce:italic>-electronic shell. The delocalization of the charges is presented in , showing in <ce:bold>6</ce:bold> an almost localized (spherical) distribution of the Laplacian_rho(r), in contrast to <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>9</ce:bold> where the delocalization of the experimental electron charge density is explicitly highlighted. Reliable quantitative characteristics of this effect can be obtained studying the energetics of the M–L bond as mentioned above. There has been evidence from many molecules that the relationship between the interaction energy and rho(r) at the bcp is approximated linearly . In this context, our efforts are indirectly addressed to the important correlative characteristics of an M–L bond associated with the energy of interactions. We use in our analysis the known expressions for G(r) and V(r) densities at the bcps (). The approximations Eqs. (19) and (20) (s.i.) hold well for covalent systems and/or those exhibiting positive Laplacian_rho(r)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>><ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0 values at the bcps . Despite this, our data ( and 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>) reveal a clear tendency that the V<ce:inf loc="post">cp</ce:inf> values for C–N and S–O multiple bonds are characterized with the lowest values, compared with single S–O, C–O and M–L bonds. In this context, the M–L interactions in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>8</ce:bold> can be addressed to the formation of predominantly ‘single’ bonds in terms bond multiplicity or delocalization of charge along the bond axis, thus excluding multiple bonding. Complex <ce:bold>9</ce:bold> shows V<ce:inf loc="post">cp</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−335.82 and −313.08<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>kJ mol<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> Bohr<ce:sup loc="post">−3</ce:sup>, which assumes multiple character of the Cu–O bonds. The application of the bond valence model as a theoretical concept applied to experimental crystallographic data in predicting the oxidation state of the Cu atoms in <ce:bold>9</ce:bold> fails to reproduce excellent correlations, by contrast to other complexes of ions with the d<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>°Configuration. The data in  show lower discrepancy coefficients for hypothetical valences of +1 and +3, by contrast the real valence +2 is marked as a less probable one. This discrepancy between the theoretical and experimental oxidation states can be explained by the open shell character of the system (<ce:bold>9</ce:bold>), which has already been highlighted as a limit of the BV model . In contrast, the employment of theoretical AIM and ESP analyses distinguishes between the different oxidation states (, models A–C, 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0020"></ce:float-anchor>, ), which correlate well to the experimental Laplacian_rho(r) of the total static ED.</ce:para>

All experimental and theoretical computational data are summarized in .

Results and discussion

Crystallographic analyses

Crystal structure of 1 

The metal-organic compound 1 has been described previously as a coordination polymer ([Ag2(HL)2(H2O)3]H2O), ) crystallizing in a centrosymmetric space group (), where two AgI centres are bridged via -SO3 - functional groups from the ligand . The redetermination of the crystal structure reported in this paper, however, reveals that the structure consists of a coordination dimer {[Ag2(HL)2(H2O)3]H2O)} n  with n =2 ( ). In addition, strong-to-moderate bonds, r(Ag-O)=2.506, 2.515Å, have been reported in . An Ag1I-Ag1I distance, r(Ag⋯Ag)=3.877Å, has been obtained as well . However a second contact interaction, Ag2I⋯Ag2I, is also determined here (r(Ag⋯Ag)=3.864Å). The AgI ion is coordinated via a deprotonated -COO- group from the ligand, which participates monodentately in the interaction with the metal ion. Each AgI ion is also bonded to two solvent water molecules as well, thus forming a distorted AgO6 polyhedron for the metal chromophore . Cumulatively, however, the crystallographic structural solution in this paper indicates two-nuclear Ag2O12 and Ag2O10 non-equivalent chromophores with bond lengths: to Ag1: r(Ag1-O): 2.634(3), 2.403(2), 2.369(3), 2.647(2), 2.515(2), 2.695(3); to Ag2: r(Ag2-O): 2.473(2), 2.415(2), 2.366(3), 2.506(3), 2.509(2)Å ().

The results of critical point analysis () and charge density models can serve as evaluation criteria for realistic inter-atomic interactions, as far as two atoms are described as chemically bonded when there are various (3,-1) bond critical points in ρ(r) between them . The Laplacian_rho(r) values<0 () correspond to charge concentration, while the Laplacian_rho(r) values>0 reflects charge depletion . The Laplacian_rho(r) is expressed as a sum of λi parameters. As the quantum chemical topology is determined by the main contributions of core electrons, it is not possible to assign participation of pairs or bonding electrons to the M-L bond formation . The ellipticity (ε) parameter also provides information about the BO (s.i.). In the case of an ideal σ-bond, this leads to λ1-λ2 and bcp =0 with λ1 and λ2 perpendicular to the bond axes, but in the mentioned ideal case there is cylindrical symmetry along the bond axis. With increasing BO an increase in ellipticity is obtained. Complex 1 reveals ε =0.001-0.028. The ε values for complexes 1-8 are 0.0-0.008, which assumes ionic character and interactions along the inter-atomic interacting axes, as well as localization of the charge, excluding the values ε =0.016, 0.018 (Ag-O) in 1 and 0.108 (Zn-N) in 7. If we compare the latter quantities with the ε values of a delocalized CO double bond from the -COO- functional group in the organic ligand of 1 (ε =0.028), then we could conclude that in these M-L bonds in 1 and 7 there is charge de-localization, which could be associated with an intra-molecular CT effect within the AgO6 (1) and ZnCl3N (7) chromophores. However, ε =0.03-0.06 in 9, considering data on the Cu-O and Cu-N bonds (). The effect of delocalization is comparable to the electronic effects in delocalized CO groups in organic ligands, even obtaining a two times greater effect. The latter result can be addressed to the electronic configuration of the Cu2+ ions (d9) and the typically observed Jahn-Teller effect removing of the degeneracy of the energies of the orbitals from the d-electronic shell. The delocalization of the charges is presented in , showing in 6 an almost localized (spherical) distribution of the Laplacian_rho(r), in contrast to 1 and 9 where the delocalization of the experimental electron charge density is explicitly highlighted. Reliable quantitative characteristics of this effect can be obtained studying the energetics of the M-L bond as mentioned above. There has been evidence from many molecules that the relationship between the interaction energy and rho(r) at the bcp is approximated linearly . In this context, our efforts are indirectly addressed to the important correlative characteristics of an M-L bond associated with the energy of interactions. We use in our analysis the known expressions for G(r) and V(r) densities at the bcps (). The approximations Eqs. (19) and (20) (s.i.) hold well for covalent systems and/or those exhibiting positive Laplacian_rho(r)>0 values at the bcps . Despite this, our data ( and  ) reveal a clear tendency that the Vcp values for C-N and S-O multiple bonds are characterized with the lowest values, compared with single S-O, C-O and M-L bonds. In this context, the M-L interactions in 1-8 can be addressed to the formation of predominantly ‘single' bonds in terms bond multiplicity or delocalization of charge along the bond axis, thus excluding multiple bonding. Complex 9 shows Vcp =-335.82 and -313.08kJ mol-1 Bohr-3, which assumes multiple character of the Cu-O bonds. The application of the bond valence model as a theoretical concept applied to experimental crystallographic data in predicting the oxidation state of the Cu atoms in 9 fails to reproduce excellent correlations, by contrast to other complexes of ions with the d1°Configuration. The data in  show lower discrepancy coefficients for hypothetical valences of +1 and +3, by contrast the real valence +2 is marked as a less probable one. This discrepancy between the theoretical and experimental oxidation states can be explained by the open shell character of the system (9), which has already been highlighted as a limit of the BV model . In contrast, the employment of theoretical AIM and ESP analyses distinguishes between the different oxidation states (, models A-C,   , ), which correlate well to the experimental Laplacian_rho(r) of the total static ED.

<ce:section-title id="st060">Quantum chemical analyses</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0055" view="all">Analysis of electrostatic interactions <ce:italic>via</ce:italic> quantum chemical computations of electrostatic potential maps illustrates electron poor and electron rich regions . Computations of the electrostatic potentials using the atomic charges (), accounting for the overlapping effect of the spherical electron charge clouds, has been regarded as the simplest model of covalent bonding . The dissociation energy in this context can be obtained by computing the co-valence curve. However correlative analyses with spectroscopic, crystallographic and thermo-chemical data have shown that theoretical bond dissociation energies (BDE) corresponded well with experiment when they are computed using models accounting for a deviation of the spherical valance electron radii of the atoms in the molecules .  depicts the 2D and 3D theoretical ESPs and the corresponding ones derived from the experimental crystallographic data. The values are shown in . In terms of the ESPs, the common electron poor space, known as the ‘σ-hole’ and is characterized with positive values of the ESPs, has been associated with an electron deficient anti-bonding orbital assigned to covalent bonding. The theoretical quantum chemical and experimental crystallographic electrostatic potentials are correlated using Poisson’s law  (Eq. (21) in the s.i.). Rho(r) represents the ED, while <ce:italic>ε</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf> is the dielectric constant. It can be simplified . The employment of DFT values for atomic ESPs () yielded the Laplacian_V(r) values. The latter calculations were carried out within the so-called transferable local distribution, where the description of the molecular ESP surface is according this approximation . In addition, a correlative analysis was carried out between the kinetic energy of the bond (E<ce:sup loc="post">KIN</ce:sup>) obtained by the AIM approach () and the V<ce:inf loc="post">cp</ce:inf> value from critical point analysis of the experimental EDs (compare data in ). Treatment of the experimental topological energetics of the M–L bonds also includes an estimation of the relationships between V<ce:inf loc="post">cr</ce:inf> (topological data) with the theoretical quantum chemical dissociation energies (D<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf>). Foremost, among the concepts of the dissociation energetics, the relationship between D<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf> and the electrostatic potentials is examined and given by Eq. (22) . The common concept in this case is that the ESP at the axial minimum (V(r<ce:inf loc="post">p</ce:inf>)) of the theoretical ED yields D<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf> within the framework of the shown parameterization (V(r) and D<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf> are in units [kcal mol<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>]). Additional correlative analysis is carried out using the concept of the dissociation energy (D<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf>) of the M–L bond in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>9</ce:bold> according to equation (23) . Our computations at T<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C yield the valid Eq. (24), where E<ce:sup loc="post">0</ce:sup> is the ground state energy of species according to the dissociation  (s.i.). All the M–L bonds of the coordination polyhedron are treated as undergoing homolytic dissociation (), because the correlation with the experimental topological energies reflects the different geometry parameters and electron densities at the bcps of the M–L bonds in the metal chromophores. The correlative analysis between V<ce:inf loc="post">cr</ce:inf> and D<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf> is shown in . The statistical tendencies seen () in Figs.  and  are discussed next. Contrary to organic compounds, where the nature of the chemical bonds is relatively well understood in thermodynamic terms, there is scarce corroborative research about the bonding type in metal-organics and inorganics on the basis of the energetics of the M–L coordination interaction . In general, obtaining high values of D<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf> in complex species is attributed to high bond strengths, which might be associated to a significant contribution of the purely electrostatic interactions, see for example . The BDE group tendencies of differently substituted {[ZnCl<ce:inf loc="post">x</ce:inf>Y<ce:inf loc="post">z</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">y</ce:sup>} chromophores seen in  provided by <ce:italic>ab initio</ce:italic> and DFT thermos-chemistry evidence low D<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf> values in the {[ZnCl<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup>} dianion. These results agree well with those predicted by AIM analysis, 75–61% ionic character of the Zn–Cl bonds and a metal to ligand CT effect of about E<ce:sup loc="post">(2)</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>∼<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>kcal<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> (). Apparently, the electrostatic interactions in this case are described as the main contributors to the formation of the {[ZnCl<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup>} complex anion. In the chromophore {ZnCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>} in <ce:bold>8</ce:bold> there is an increase in the D<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf> values at about ∼0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>a.u., which indicates an increase in the bond strengths. The latter phenomenon could be associated with a ligand to metal CT effect at about E<ce:sup loc="post">(2)</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>∼<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>34<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>kcal<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> () with participation of coordinated N-centres to the inner coordination sphere, which affects the Zn–Cl bonding strength. A direct confirmation follows from the obtained D<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf> values of the Zn–N bond in the same chromophores compared with the corresponding values of {ZnCl<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>N} in <ce:bold>7</ce:bold>. In the latter case D<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf> is about |0.03| a.u. higher than this one for the Z–N bond in <ce:bold>8</ce:bold>. It is especially evident from the relationship between the D<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf> values of Zn–Cl as a function of N-content in the inner coordination sphere of {[ZnCl<ce:inf loc="post">x</ce:inf>Y<ce:inf loc="post">z</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">y</ce:sup>} chromophores. A confidence level of 93% was obtained, approximating the latter relationship to a linear function. Clearly, there is a deviation from the 100% confidence level, which is explained by the chance of the electronic configuration of the Zn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> ion depending on the content of the N centres in the inner coordination sphere. On studying the i<ce:inf loc="post">AB</ce:inf> values for the ZnCl<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>N chomophore in <ce:bold>7</ce:bold>, a decrease of about 6.5% in the ionic character compared to the ZnCl<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> chromophore is obtained (i<ce:inf loc="post">AB</ce:inf>∼−0.71 in <ce:bold>7</ce:bold>, ).</ce:para><ce:para id="p0065" view="all">Computations of the natural ionicity <ce:italic>i</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">AB</ce:inf> of the {[ZnCl<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup>} chromophore in <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> shows an i<ce:inf loc="post">ab</ce:inf> value of about −0.76 for all Zn–Cl bonds (), indicating an almost purely ionic hybrid at the Cl centers. The data correlates well to computations for the AIM Laplacian of the total ED (). There is also an excellent agreement with the data for the hybrid directionality (), showing a small deviation from the direct line of the nuclear interaction with an s-type character of the hybrids (the large deviation ‘Dev” in  reflects a <ce:sup loc="post">π</ce:sup>-nature for the interaction). With E<ce:sup loc="post">(2)</ce:sup> values of ∼2.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>kcal<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, there is little argument about a significant CT effect (). The results, therefore, correlate well with the ESP ones, showing the following electrostatic properties: Zn (−29.32<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>a.u.) and Cl (−64.76, −64.76, −64.76 and −64.76 a.u.). These conclusions are confirmed further by computation of the experimental static ED, as presented (). The data obtained on the basis of the Couloson orthogonality theorem for ω<ce:inf loc="post">ij</ce:inf> (s.i.) of metal hybrids sdm, yields an ω<ce:inf loc="post">ij</ce:inf> angle for Cl2–Zn1–Cl3 of 101.48°, which correlates excellently to the experimental crystallographic data, which shows an angle of 104.4(2)° . We should stress here that the generally detected {[ZnCl<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup>} anion in tetrachlorozincate(II) containing crystals  could be assigned only to the major contribution of mainly electrostatic interactions with only intra-ionic factors governing its thermodynamic stability (). Nevertheless, this structural discrete unit is generally broadly distributed in metal-organics with Zn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> containing ions . Moreover, as broadly discussed in the literature, the valuable properties of the {[ZnCl<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2-</ce:sup>} containing anion in metal–organic multi-functional materials could be assigned to contributions due to the charged interacting character of the ions in the {[ZnCl<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup>} unit, excluding additional n-s interactions, as further AIM analysis of multi-pole moments reveal small total values of −0.067125 (XX), −0.029897 (YY), 0.097023 (ZZ), 0.001539 (XY), 0.002867 (XZ) and 0.006198 (YZ). The AIM analysis about the localized orbital energies and BOs indicate a possible ionic character of the interaction, of 69.2–75.6%, which correlates well to the NBO data stated above (). On the contrary for Zn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> complexes, the i<ce:inf loc="post">AB</ce:inf> values of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are −0.288 and −0.0049. The latter results assume that the Ag<ce:sup loc="post">I</ce:sup> ions tend to form covalent coordination bonds with N centers in the inner coordination sphere. This result agrees well with the topological potential energy of the Ag–N bonds in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, showing the lowest V<ce:inf loc="post">cr</ce:inf> ∼0.1 a.u. Bohr<ce:sup loc="post">−3</ce:sup> among the studied series, which indicates a low bond strength due to the lack of a strong contribution of the purely electrostatic interactions, as observed in the case of the Zn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> containing complexes.</ce:para>

Quantum chemical analyses

Analysis of electrostatic interactions via quantum chemical computations of electrostatic potential maps illustrates electron poor and electron rich regions . Computations of the electrostatic potentials using the atomic charges (), accounting for the overlapping effect of the spherical electron charge clouds, has been regarded as the simplest model of covalent bonding . The dissociation energy in this context can be obtained by computing the co-valence curve. However correlative analyses with spectroscopic, crystallographic and thermo-chemical data have shown that theoretical bond dissociation energies (BDE) corresponded well with experiment when they are computed using models accounting for a deviation of the spherical valance electron radii of the atoms in the molecules .  depicts the 2D and 3D theoretical ESPs and the corresponding ones derived from the experimental crystallographic data. The values are shown in . In terms of the ESPs, the common electron poor space, known as the ‘σ-hole' and is characterized with positive values of the ESPs, has been associated with an electron deficient anti-bonding orbital assigned to covalent bonding. The theoretical quantum chemical and experimental crystallographic electrostatic potentials are correlated using Poisson's law  (Eq. (21) in the s.i.). Rho(r) represents the ED, while ε 0 is the dielectric constant. It can be simplified . The employment of DFT values for atomic ESPs () yielded the Laplacian_V(r) values. The latter calculations were carried out within the so-called transferable local distribution, where the description of the molecular ESP surface is according this approximation . In addition, a correlative analysis was carried out between the kinetic energy of the bond (EKIN) obtained by the AIM approach () and the Vcp value from critical point analysis of the experimental EDs (compare data in ). Treatment of the experimental topological energetics of the M-L bonds also includes an estimation of the relationships between Vcr (topological data) with the theoretical quantum chemical dissociation energies (D0). Foremost, among the concepts of the dissociation energetics, the relationship between D0 and the electrostatic potentials is examined and given by Eq. (22) . The common concept in this case is that the ESP at the axial minimum (V(rp)) of the theoretical ED yields D0 within the framework of the shown parameterization (V(r) and D0 are in units [kcal mol-1]). Additional correlative analysis is carried out using the concept of the dissociation energy (D0) of the M-L bond in 1-9 according to equation (23) . Our computations at T=0°C yield the valid Eq. (24), where E0 is the ground state energy of species according to the dissociation  (s.i.). All the M-L bonds of the coordination polyhedron are treated as undergoing homolytic dissociation (), because the correlation with the experimental topological energies reflects the different geometry parameters and electron densities at the bcps of the M-L bonds in the metal chromophores. The correlative analysis between Vcr and D0 is shown in . The statistical tendencies seen () in Figs.  and  are discussed next. Contrary to organic compounds, where the nature of the chemical bonds is relatively well understood in thermodynamic terms, there is scarce corroborative research about the bonding type in metal-organics and inorganics on the basis of the energetics of the M-L coordination interaction . In general, obtaining high values of D0 in complex species is attributed to high bond strengths, which might be associated to a significant contribution of the purely electrostatic interactions, see for example . The BDE group tendencies of differently substituted {[ZnClxYz]y} chromophores seen in  provided by ab initio and DFT thermos-chemistry evidence low D0 values in the {[ZnCl4]2-} dianion. These results agree well with those predicted by AIM analysis, 75-61% ionic character of the Zn-Cl bonds and a metal to ligand CT effect of about E(2) ~2kcalmol-1 (). Apparently, the electrostatic interactions in this case are described as the main contributors to the formation of the {[ZnCl4]2-} complex anion. In the chromophore {ZnCl2N2} in 8 there is an increase in the D0 values at about ~0.2a.u., which indicates an increase in the bond strengths. The latter phenomenon could be associated with a ligand to metal CT effect at about E(2) ~34kcalmol-1 () with participation of coordinated N-centres to the inner coordination sphere, which affects the Zn-Cl bonding strength. A direct confirmation follows from the obtained D0 values of the Zn-N bond in the same chromophores compared with the corresponding values of {ZnCl3N} in 7. In the latter case D0 is about |0.03| a.u. higher than this one for the Z-N bond in 8. It is especially evident from the relationship between the D0 values of Zn-Cl as a function of N-content in the inner coordination sphere of {[ZnClxYz]y} chromophores. A confidence level of 93% was obtained, approximating the latter relationship to a linear function. Clearly, there is a deviation from the 100% confidence level, which is explained by the chance of the electronic configuration of the ZnII ion depending on the content of the N centres in the inner coordination sphere. On studying the iAB values for the ZnCl3N chomophore in 7, a decrease of about 6.5% in the ionic character compared to the ZnCl4 chromophore is obtained (iAB~-0.71 in 7, ).

Computations of the natural ionicity i AB of the {[ZnCl4]2-} chromophore in 4 shows an iab value of about -0.76 for all Zn-Cl bonds (), indicating an almost purely ionic hybrid at the Cl centers. The data correlates well to computations for the AIM Laplacian of the total ED (). There is also an excellent agreement with the data for the hybrid directionality (), showing a small deviation from the direct line of the nuclear interaction with an s-type character of the hybrids (the large deviation ‘Dev" in  reflects a π-nature for the interaction). With E(2) values of ~2.5kcalmol-1, there is little argument about a significant CT effect (). The results, therefore, correlate well with the ESP ones, showing the following electrostatic properties: Zn (-29.32a.u.) and Cl (-64.76, -64.76, -64.76 and -64.76 a.u.). These conclusions are confirmed further by computation of the experimental static ED, as presented (). The data obtained on the basis of the Couloson orthogonality theorem for ωij (s.i.) of metal hybrids sdm, yields an ωij angle for Cl2-Zn1-Cl3 of 101.48°, which correlates excellently to the experimental crystallographic data, which shows an angle of 104.4(2)° . We should stress here that the generally detected {[ZnCl4]2-} anion in tetrachlorozincate(II) containing crystals  could be assigned only to the major contribution of mainly electrostatic interactions with only intra-ionic factors governing its thermodynamic stability (). Nevertheless, this structural discrete unit is generally broadly distributed in metal-organics with ZnII containing ions . Moreover, as broadly discussed in the literature, the valuable properties of the {[ZnCl4]2-} containing anion in metal-organic multi-functional materials could be assigned to contributions due to the charged interacting character of the ions in the {[ZnCl4]2-} unit, excluding additional n-s interactions, as further AIM analysis of multi-pole moments reveal small total values of -0.067125 (XX), -0.029897 (YY), 0.097023 (ZZ), 0.001539 (XY), 0.002867 (XZ) and 0.006198 (YZ). The AIM analysis about the localized orbital energies and BOs indicate a possible ionic character of the interaction, of 69.2-75.6%, which correlates well to the NBO data stated above (). On the contrary for ZnII complexes, the iAB values of 1 and 2 are -0.288 and -0.0049. The latter results assume that the AgI ions tend to form covalent coordination bonds with N centers in the inner coordination sphere. This result agrees well with the topological potential energy of the Ag-N bonds in 2, showing the lowest Vcr ~0.1 a.u. Bohr-3 among the studied series, which indicates a low bond strength due to the lack of a strong contribution of the purely electrostatic interactions, as observed in the case of the ZnII containing complexes.

<ce:para id="p0070" view="all">Employment of the BV methodology yields a probable valence of the Zn<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> ion in {[ZnCl<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup>} of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> (), which fits excellently to the crystallographic refinement of the structure assuming the oxidation state Zn<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> and coincidence of the oxidation and valence states. The crystallographic <ce:italic>r</ce:italic>(Zn–Cl) bond lengths are 2.282, 2.262, 2.274 and 2.238<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, which assumes a T<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">d</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> symmetry of the metal chromophore, and we further attempted to correlate the crystallographic geometries and BOs obtained by the two completely different methods of NBO and AIM (). Preliminary, it is important to point out that, as it was shown above, the BO values according the AIM computations lack rigorous application and thus they cannot be direct correlated as quantities with the NBO bond orders. However, the BO values shown in  assume a lack of bonding interactions according to the description already written in the theory and computations section, which qualitatively correlates with the conclusions about the BO values from NBO analysis, with values obtained in the ranges 0.3114–0.3245 and 0.2882–0.3025 (NLMO), indicating the lack of complete single bond formation. The latter data seek to provide additional evidence to support the statements above by analysing the natural ionicity parameters. The predicted hybridization of the d-orbitals of the Zn<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> ion by the AIM method () agrees well with the obtained natural electronic configuration for Zn: s<ce:sup loc="post">0.58</ce:sup>3d<ce:sup loc="post">9.99</ce:sup>4p<ce:sup loc="post">0.72</ce:sup>5p<ce:sup loc="post">0.02</ce:sup>. The same conclusions are obtained employing fuzzy and Laplacian bond orders (Figs. 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0025"></ce:float-anchor> and ). In all cases positive LBOs are found, which assumes a lack of covalent bonding. The correlative analysis performed between the geometry bond lengths, FBOs and LBOs shows a linear relationship with confidence levels of 99.96–96.98%. The correspondence of the chemometric data between the FBO and LBO values indicates unexpectedly high confidence levels (98.67–89.14%). These good-to-excellent linear extrapolation data are mainly found correlating BOs and bond lengths of the metal chromophore in Zn<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> complexes with the strong electronegative Cl<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ligand or for cases when strong electron localization occurs. On the contrary, complexes of Ag<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> and Cu<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> ions, due to 2D delocalization, exhibit a decreasing reliability of the linear extrapolation. Confidence levels of 82 (<ce:bold>8</ce:bold>) and 61% (<ce:bold>9</ce:bold>) are obtained. However, the results concerning the latter cases of strongly delocalized systems do not clearly indicate a non-linear correlation. On this basis, it might be concluded that further systematic correlative analyses are needed between theoretical and experimental EDs of Ag<ce:sup loc="post">I</ce:sup> and Cu<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> complexes to determine any quantitative correlations, including distinguishing between the coordination behaviour between both ions, as there is no obvious explanation, even interpreting the results on the basis of the concept of the d9d’ configuration of the Ag<ce:sup loc="post">I</ce:sup> ions presented above, for the similar behaviour of Ag<ce:sup loc="post">I</ce:sup> and Cu<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> ions. In the latter case, there is the well known strong Jahn–Teller effect. The data of the statistical analyses on the nature of the Zn–Cl bond in T<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">d</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> ZnCl<ce:inf loc="post">x</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">y</ce:inf> chromophores as a function of the content of N centres in the inner coordination sphere, showing a linear correlation, allow the conclusion that even purely ionic interactions between the charged species, like Zn<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> and Cl<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ions, could be affected by other non-covalent interactions within the framework of the inner coordination sphere. If we use the above discussed concept about the LBO, where negative values are associated with the covalence of the corresponding bond, then with increasing N centres (<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0–2) there is an increase in the LBOs, which indicates a further increase in the ionic character of the Zn–Cl bonds. From the perspective of the latter BOs analyses, it can be said that the FBO and LBO results fit well to the natural electronic configurations, which in the case of the Ag<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> ions in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> are Ag1 s<ce:sup loc="post">0.20</ce:sup>4d<ce:sup loc="post">5.00</ce:sup>5p<ce:sup loc="post">0.11</ce:sup>6d<ce:sup loc="post">0.01</ce:sup>7p<ce:sup loc="post">0.01</ce:sup>, Ag19 s<ce:sup loc="post">0.99</ce:sup>4d<ce:sup loc="post">5.00</ce:sup>5p<ce:sup loc="post">2.80</ce:sup>6s<ce:sup loc="post">0.01</ce:sup>5d<ce:sup loc="post">0.30</ce:sup>6p<ce:sup loc="post">0.18</ce:sup>7s<ce:sup loc="post">0.17</ce:sup>6d<ce:sup loc="post">0.02</ce:sup> and Ag24 s<ce:sup loc="post">1.00</ce:sup>4d<ce:sup loc="post">5.00</ce:sup>5p<ce:sup loc="post">2.89</ce:sup>6s<ce:sup loc="post">0.33</ce:sup>5d<ce:sup loc="post">0.82</ce:sup>6p<ce:sup loc="post">0.27</ce:sup>6d<ce:sup loc="post">0.02</ce:sup>, thus indicating a significant orbital delocalization of the ED, by contrast to the Zn<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> complexes where a configuration for Zn1 of s<ce:sup loc="post">0.44</ce:sup>3d<ce:sup loc="post">9.98</ce:sup>4p<ce:sup loc="post">0.59</ce:sup>4d<ce:sup loc="post">0.01</ce:sup>5p<ce:sup loc="post">0.01</ce:sup> is obtained. Additional confirmation can be obtained by examining the NBO E<ce:sup loc="post">(2)</ce:sup> values for complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, where by contrast to the Zn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> complex discussed above (E<ce:sup loc="post">(2)</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>∼<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>kcal<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>), the E<ce:sup loc="post">(2)</ce:sup> values of the Ag1O<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> unit (complexes) are in the range 1.77–11.35<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>kcal<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. The values provide significant evidence about the CT effects. By contrast, the E<ce:sup loc="post">(2)</ce:sup> values for the complex unit (Ag19-Ag24)O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> are in the range 0.04–0.13<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>kcal<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. An exception is seen for the E<ce:sup loc="post">(2)</ce:sup>
<ce:inf loc="post">D→A</ce:inf> value of 3.69<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>kcal<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, corresponding to the M<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>→<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>L CT effect between the Ag19–O22(SO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>) fragment.</ce:para>
cln_elements.clean_text: Employment of the BV methodology yields a probable valence of the Zn2+ ion in {[ZnCl4]2-} of 2 (), which fits excellently to the crystallographic refinement of the structure assuming the oxidation state Zn2+ and coincidence of the oxidation and valence states. The crystallographic r(Zn-Cl) bond lengths are 2.282, 2.262, 2.274 and 2.238Å, which assumes a T d  symmetry of the metal chromophore, and we further attempted to correlate the crystallographic geometries and BOs obtained by the two completely different methods of NBO and AIM (). Preliminary, it is important to point out that, as it was shown above, the BO values according the AIM computations lack rigorous application and thus they cannot be direct correlated as quantities with the NBO bond orders. However, the BO values shown in  assume a lack of bonding interactions according to the description already written in the theory and computations section, which qualitatively correlates with the conclusions about the BO values from NBO analysis, with values obtained in the ranges 0.3114-0.3245 and 0.2882-0.3025 (NLMO), indicating the lack of complete single bond formation. The latter data seek to provide additional evidence to support the statements above by analysing the natural ionicity parameters. The predicted hybridization of the d-orbitals of the Zn2+ ion by the AIM method () agrees well with the obtained natural electronic configuration for Zn: s0.583d9.994p0.725p0.02. The same conclusions are obtained employing fuzzy and Laplacian bond orders (Figs.   and ). In all cases positive LBOs are found, which assumes a lack of covalent bonding. The correlative analysis performed between the geometry bond lengths, FBOs and LBOs shows a linear relationship with confidence levels of 99.96-96.98%. The correspondence of the chemometric data between the FBO and LBO values indicates unexpectedly high confidence levels (98.67-89.14%). These good-to-excellent linear extrapolation data are mainly found correlating BOs and bond lengths of the metal chromophore in Zn2+ complexes with the strong electronegative Cl- ligand or for cases when strong electron localization occurs. On the contrary, complexes of Ag+ and Cu2+ ions, due to 2D delocalization, exhibit a decreasing reliability of the linear extrapolation. Confidence levels of 82 (8) and 61% (9) are obtained. However, the results concerning the latter cases of strongly delocalized systems do not clearly indicate a non-linear correlation. On this basis, it might be concluded that further systematic correlative analyses are needed between theoretical and experimental EDs of AgI and CuII complexes to determine any quantitative correlations, including distinguishing between the coordination behaviour between both ions, as there is no obvious explanation, even interpreting the results on the basis of the concept of the d9d' configuration of the AgI ions presented above, for the similar behaviour of AgI and CuII ions. In the latter case, there is the well known strong Jahn-Teller effect. The data of the statistical analyses on the nature of the Zn-Cl bond in T d  ZnClxNy chromophores as a function of the content of N centres in the inner coordination sphere, showing a linear correlation, allow the conclusion that even purely ionic interactions between the charged species, like Zn2+ and Cl- ions, could be affected by other non-covalent interactions within the framework of the inner coordination sphere. If we use the above discussed concept about the LBO, where negative values are associated with the covalence of the corresponding bond, then with increasing N centres (x =0-2) there is an increase in the LBOs, which indicates a further increase in the ionic character of the Zn-Cl bonds. From the perspective of the latter BOs analyses, it can be said that the FBO and LBO results fit well to the natural electronic configurations, which in the case of the Ag+ ions in 1 are Ag1 s0.204d5.005p0.116d0.017p0.01, Ag19 s0.994d5.005p2.806s0.015d0.306p0.187s0.176d0.02 and Ag24 s1.004d5.005p2.896s0.335d0.826p0.276d0.02, thus indicating a significant orbital delocalization of the ED, by contrast to the Zn2+ complexes where a configuration for Zn1 of s0.443d9.984p0.594d0.015p0.01 is obtained. Additional confirmation can be obtained by examining the NBO E(2) values for complex 1, where by contrast to the ZnII complex discussed above (E(2) ~2.5kcalmol-1), the E(2) values of the Ag1O6 unit (complexes) are in the range 1.77-11.35kcalmol-1. The values provide significant evidence about the CT effects. By contrast, the E(2) values for the complex unit (Ag19-Ag24)O2 are in the range 0.04-0.13kcalmol-1. An exception is seen for the E(2) D→A value of 3.69kcalmol-1, corresponding to the M→L CT effect between the Ag19-O22(SO2) fragment.

metadata.title: On the nature of the coordination bonding of metal–organics for ions with the d10 electronic configuration – Experimental and theoretical analyses
